_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
St. Charles Parish Department of Wastewater

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION and EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Accidental Release Prevention: St. Charles Parish and the Department of Wastewater are committed to the safe operation of the Luling Oxidation Pond. Continuous review of standard operating procedures (SOP's) and mechanical integrity programs help to ensure that the chlorine system is operated and maintained in a safe manner. The Department provides formal training for all operators and Mintenance personnel focusing on chlorine safety. Annual audits are conducted by representatives of the Parish Emergency Operations Center (EOC) to familiarize themselves with the chlorine system.

Emergency Response Policies: Operators at the Luling Oxidation Pond will not respond to leaks beyond their ability to control through the use of valves. In the event of such a release, plant personnelwill notify EOC and evacuate the area. EOC will establish the safe perimeter and begin public notification. EOC will handle all emergency procedures and evacuation. The facility is included in the Local Emergency Planning Committee's community emergency response plan.

THE WESTBANK WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

The Luling Oxidation Pond (Pond) is a 2.2 million gallons per day oxidation pond that serves the Luling area of St. Charles Parish. Treated effluent from the plant is discharged to the George Cousins Canal. Disinfection of the effluent is accomplished by injecting chlorine into the effluent box. Chlorine is stored in a maximum of six one ton cylinders. The Pond is owned and operated by the Parish.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM and CHLORINE RELEASE PREVENTION

The critical elements that the Parish uses to prevent accidental releases are the recently reviewed and updated Standard Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity Program, and Training Program. These three programs have a significant impact in the continued safe operation of the chlorine s

ystem.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There was one accidental release of chlorine in the past five years. On 9/24/2002 a small release occurred as a result of operator error in failing to follow established standard operating procedures. There were no offsite consequences.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

As described above, personnel at the Pond will not act as responders to uncontrollable releases of chlorine. Instead, the Emergency Action Plan will be implemented which notifies the Parish EOC. EOC will provide support and technical assistance to contain chlorine releases beyond the ability of Parish personnel. The Pond is included in the community emergency response plan for the Parish of St. Charles.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Parish is investigating the feasibility of ultraviolet radiation as a disinfection source instead of chlorine.
